results.raw: Protesters and Police Clashing in Brooklyn Center at 6645 Humboldt Ave N, Minneapolis, Minnesota, 55430
results.title: Protesters and Police Clashing in Brooklyn Center

-MY7iiq7P9kQGQFBDuG0.text: Incident reported at 6645 Humboldt Ave N.

-MY7ij3KDd6l4JJxs0Cq.text: Police are monitoring several hundred protesters demonstrating outside of the Brooklyn Center Police Department.

-MY7itdmgyXPtIIMdJWP.text: National Guard personnel report the protesters have begun throwing hazardous objects.

-MY7iy59bsmFviUt6UEm.text: According to National Guard units at the scene, several officers are preparing to deploy smoke bombs in an effort to disperse the crowd.

-MY7q9VDQPREtv051h29.text: Units on scene report the protesters may also be weaponizing lasers.

-MY7qEvf-sAullx9osZI.text: Additional sources at the scene advise police may be armed with rubber bullets or PepperBalls. Police have also begun deploying smoke bombs.

-MY7tG0iyt5lBKi1JOfv.text: Video footage from local sources shows police using what appear to be stun grenades to disperse the crowd.

-MY7xIrJ_WzGyRjxnQPp.text: National Guard personnel report the protesters have begun weaponizing bricks, glass bottles, and lasers. Police have begun deploying CS grenades and other less-lethal weaponry to disperse the crowd.

-MY7ygXUirNKyKB-gihC.text: According to an update provided by Minnesota's Operation Safety Net via Twitter, law enforcement personnel have begun arresting members of the crowd for violating curfew and dispersal orders.

-MY80wxgdSuIcgNQR7Yi.text: According to additional sources from the scene, Minnesota State Police are expanding their perimeter and mobilizing towards protesters.

nib.text:
Demonstrators gathered outside of the Brooklyn Center Police Department Monday night, one day after Daunte Wright was shot and killed by police during a traffic stop.

A 7 p.m. curfew went into effect in Hennepin County and the surrounding counties of Anoka, Dakota, and Ramsey.

Hundreds of people remained after curfew outside of the police building, which was fenced off, despite multiple dispersal orders from law enforcement. 

Video from local media and those in the crowd showed law enforcement deploying tear gas and flash-bang canisters.

Officers warned that curfew violations would result in misdemeanor charges for anyone arrested.

Citizen will provide more details on this developing story.

results.raw: Hennepin, Ramsey, Anoka, and Dakota Counties Under Curfew Beginning at 7 P.M. Monday at Minneapolis-St Paul Int'l Airport
results.title: Hennepin, Ramsey, Anoka, and Dakota Counties Under Curfew Beginning at 7 P.M. Monday

-MY6_ZDc4yx4NvUL3z4n.text: Incident reported at Minneapolis-St Paul Int'l Airport.

-MY6_ZKSBV2OGuEEdtxg.text: Governor Walz announced that Hennepin, Ramsey, and Anoka counties will be under a curfew from 7 p.m. Monday until 6 a.m. Tuesday.

-MY7TqWIvBAURQ0uU5vy.text: Dakota County officials said they will observe the regional curfew as well.

nib.text:
Residents of Hennepin, Ramsey, Dakota, and Anoka counties will be under curfew starting 7 p.m. Monday night until 6 a.m. Tuesday morning. 

State and local officials announced there would be exemptions for credentialed press, law enforcement, emergency responders, those traveling to and from work, and community patrols.

Minneapolis Mayor Jacob Frey noted the curfews are in response to the police shooting of Daunte Wright in Brooklyn Center. This anguish that were all suffering cannot translate into violence  We must see peace tonight, Mayor Frey said in the Monday afternoon briefing.

Major General Shawn Manke of the MN National Guard added that Guard deployments would expand from 500 personnel as of Monday morning to over 1,000 by the end of the day in order to support Phase 3 of Operation Safety Net. He said they would be deployed throughout Minneapolis, St. Paul, and Brooklyn Center.

Additional personnel will be placed in staging areas until they are assigned specific missions and shift rotations based on needs and conditions on the ground.

Manke dispelled rumors that the guard has used nonlethal munitions in and around Minneapolis-St Paul.

We are committed to meeting the intent of Operation Safety Net, to protect the communities and the people while preserving their constitutional rights and the peaceful expression of First Amendment Rights, he said.

nib.text:
A 20-year-old man was shot and killed by police during a traffic stop in Brooklyn Center on Sunday after a responding officer discharged their firearm, rather than their Taser, during the stop. 

On Monday afternoon, Brooklyn Center Mayor Mike Elliot and Chief of Police Tim Gannon provided an update on the fatal shooting of 20-year-old Daunte Wright and shared body camera footage from the scene. 

In the footage, the Chief indicated the officer can be heard shouting taser, taser before discharging their firearm. Chief Gannon stated that this shouting indicated to him that the officer meant to use their taser, not discharge the firearm. 

"As I watch the video and listen to the officer's commands it is my belief that the officer had the intention to deploy their taser but instead shot Mr. Wright with a single bullet, this appears to me, from what I viewed, and the officer's reaction in distress immediately after, that this was an accidental discharge," Gannon said. 

When asked by a member of the press, Mayor Elliot stated that he supported releasing the officer of her duties. 

Chief Gannon indicated that specific details about the officer in question will be released by the Minnesota Department of Public Safety Bureau of Criminal Apprehension (BCA) as part of their ongoing investigation. According to Brooklyn Center City Manager Kurt Boganey any disciplinary action will wait until the officer has received due process. 

In an [overnight briefing](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gm43yp5ohLU) early Monday morning, John Harrington, the Commissioner of the Minnesota Department of Public Safety, provided details on what led to the fatal shooting. 

Harrington stated that Wright was pulled over for a traffic violation around 2 p.m Sunday afternoon on Orchard Avenue North. 

During the stop, police learned that Wright had an outstanding warrant and attempted to arrest him. During the attempt, Wright tried to re-enter his vehicle for an unspecified reason. 

The body camera footage shared by Chief Gannon showed a brief struggle as Wright attempted to get back into the vehicle. It is during this struggle that the officer can be heard shouting Taser, Taser and discharges her firearm. 

After he was shot, Wrights vehicle drove several blocks and crashed into another vehicle. 

Wright was pronounced deceased at the scene. A woman who had been in Wrights car and the other vehicles occupants were all transported to an area hospital with minor injuries. 

Commissioner Harrington stated the BCA would be looking at the body camera footage and taking statements but did not provide further information due to their ongoing investigation. 

Protesters had gathered in Brooklyn Center and across the Twin Cities on Sunday in response to the shooting. 

At least 100 people were initially gathered at the scene of the shooting before peacefully dispersing. The [Star Tribune](https://www.startribune.com/brooklyn-center-police-fatally-shoot-man-20-inflaming-tensions-during-the-derek-chauvin-trial/600044821/?refresh=true) reported that Wrights family members were among the assembled group and offered an account of the shooting different than the one presented by authorities.  

Soon after, officials report that a group of as many as 200 people were gathered at the Brooklyn Center police headquarters. The group allegedly threw rocks and other objects at the building. 

Live video from the headquarters showed police officers lined up across the street as protesters continued gathering in the area. 

Police in the Twin Cities also responded to reports of break-ins and looting throughout the night. Commissioner Harrington noted that officers and members of the National Guard responded to the Shingle Creek Business Center after at least 20 businesses were broken into. 

On Monday morning, the inter-agency group Minnesota Operation Safety Net [announced](https://twitter.com/MinnesotaOSN/status/1381602217694728196) that 500 National Guard personnel were currently activated across the Twin Cities, and that number would increase following Sundays officer-involved shooting.

Harrington stated that the operation was moving into Phase 3, a full activation of all state officers, which had been originally reserved for closing arguments and deliberation of the trial of former Minneapolis police officer Derek Chauvin.

He said the Guard would work with state and local police departments over the next few days to prepare for civil unrest that may come from either the Chauvin trial or the Brooklyn Center shooting.
